text: <@U337FMTFE> It's usually done the other way. Firstly check the permissions and then, everytime u need to use the feature, check if location service is enabled :slightly_smiling_face:
Actually you need to check both of these because after granting permission user can always revoke permission manually from app's settings

Hi everyone! Hope you’re having a fantastic day/night (depending where you at) :slightly_smiling_face:
I’ve stumbled upon an issue and thought it would be appropriate to ask android gurus here.
So the question is how can one measure the time spent on the loading and displaying images? Specifically I want to measure it for Picasso and Fresco to find out which one is the most efficient and the fastest one. Any advice is much appreciated!
Hah, Fresco... U funny.
I think slackbot just answered you :joy:
the general consensus is that Fresco does bad things for your app by fiddling with the native memory directly
Hah, Fresco... U funny.
it solves a FB problem _for_ FB
glide/picasso are much better in most normal cases
also introduce way less weird errors in the long run

Can someone explain to me what Notification.setColor (); actually achieves? I am setting a Red color but the smallIcon & Title comes out a dark purple color. If I remove setColor it comes out a generic light blue color.

I just started a side project with one of my friend. I have to make a travel experience sharing app. So the obvious first step is registration and then login of the user. Now what are the best practices to store username and its details(Name,password etc.) . I can store them in shared prefs but that is probably a bad practice.
sqlite.
I can save it in a db but isn't there anything like android default key or password protector or collector?
<http://www.androidauthority.com/where-is-the-best-place-to-store-a-password-in-your-android-app-597197/> ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

attachments.text: Storing personal information inside an Android app can be a security risk, but sometimes it is necessary. So, where is the best place to store passwords?

text: <https://androidsecurity.info/2016/12/15/storing-your-secure-information-in-the-ndk/>

attachments.title: Storing your secure information in the NDK
attachments.text: Reverse engineering and tampering can be easily accomplished in Android. There are measures you can take to stop hackers from tampering with your Android applications, but ultimately a determined hacker will always have the last say.
attachments.fallback: Android Security: Storing your secure information in the NDK

text:
Hi all, I'm having problems implementing DELETE in retrofit.
I have the following URL to delete a product from shopping cart. 
<https://testshoppingcart.com/cart/cartId>


It just returns Response 204


How do I implement this in retrofit? Is it something like this:

Call<Void> deleteItemFromCart(@Path("id") int cartId);
which is the retrofit version you are using?
Retrofit 2 <@U04U01U4H>
BaseURL should be `<https://testshoppingcart.com/>`
the API interface thing should be `cart/cartId`
technically it should be `cart/{cartId}`
and then it's `@DELETE  Call<Void> deleteItemFromCart(@Path("cartId") int cardId);` although I'm slightly uncertain about the Void
<@U39P7U6EP> actually doesn’t matter if you have a  `/` in path or not
Sorry I meant `@DELETE("cart/{cartId}"` silly me
<@U1FECKXA9>
Who was that guy who modified retrofit to accept custom HTTP methods
I think you can actually do that anyway in retrofit
@HTTP(method = "DELETE", path = "/foo", hasBody = true)
you can of course put any METHOD
it was okhttp
that’s interesting
still - okhttp would still kill it
this just exists to either create a request body or not
I see
Guys, I'm working on a project that uses Clean Architecture + MVP
But I need to implement a Bluetooth connection, and that is the point hahaha
I created a BluetoothHelper in my data (or infrastucture) layer to manage all Bluetooth stuff
And a ConnectionRepository to provide the list of available devices to connect
But I bugged my mind because of the bluetooth needs to connect with an specific device
And I think my architecture is not so great because I have a connection repository to manage it
What do you recommend or use in this case?
Do you have any example about Bluetooth on Clean Architecture / MVP?
<@U3FRYA136|emce> has joined the channel
I'm working on a project pretty much the same as yours, <@U2B3MLARY> except for sockets instead of bluetooth
check out what I did here, in the infrastructure layer: <https://github.com/RemotecraftProject/RemotecraftApp/tree/feature/search_server>
I'm using RxJava though
Thats nice
Thank you <@U201VGZK7>

Hi guys, I have something to consult about. I am developing my pet project. I have some data that the user adds  on the phone and I want his other devices to get this data as well (e.g. CRUD operation on data). I also wanted my user to get updated from his/her PC. I am looking at Realm and Firebase but I dont know which one is better for mobile. I also don't know if Realm and Firebase works for windows program, say, that is written in Java. Also, it is important that my app works offline. I am a solo dev and don't have the resources (money, manpower, etc.) to maintain a server for this app and wanted to work with existing solution. I am currently thinking of using Firebase, AWS, and Realm. Realm seems to be nice, with their DB and all that and now they have a complete platform which seems I have to develop and maintain. I also dont see any options to include PC from sync from the 3 options I provided. Unless I missed it entirely but they kept on mentioning mobile devices. My scope is Android->Windows. Any thoughts on these?
I am having some trouble figuring out Stickyheaders for recyclerview with multiple viewtypes. If anyone has some experience, I would like to ask some questions.
whats this sticky headers?
actually I have implemented a recycler view with different view types
for instance I have a Header item which always stays as the first item of the list
one of the key method to consider here is RecyclerView.Adapter#getItemViewType(int position) and on onCreateViewHolder just
inflate a different layout and insert that to your view holder
you can have to view holders for different views if desired
what I usually do is that I have a parent holder
just basically holding an item type ID and the root view
something like this
